posts.sub: Do you take pictures or film when you travel?
posts.com: I used to take photos before, never ever filmed. But nowadays i've stopped doing that completely. Went to Japan for 3 weeks and came home with like 10 photos, had a great time. Went to Thailand for a month, not a single photo. I feel that filming or taking photos of everything robs one of really experiencing the moment. I get that some people want to make money from it or look back at it later, but come on, its constant snapping and filming everything, all the time. Full-time job. Walked into a random ramen place in Tokyo and every foreigner was taking a picture of their food. Went to Bali and everyone was filming everything, running around with DJIs and GoPros. Is this how its going to be like from now on? Youtube is littered with travel vlogs and all kinds of walking tours and shit everywhere. Is it necessary? Do we feel like we're missing out if we don't have proof of our experience? Are we tricking ourselves? Are we looking for constant validation now? Who gives a shit?

I take photos for 2 reasons
> have a collage of my photos on my tv screensaver, so I randomly see photos from years ago and remember those times.
> show photos to my grand parents, as they never got the chance to travel and see something of the world that way.

I usually take a few quick snaps for a few seconds, then put my phone away and enjoy the moment. Afterwards I delete the blurry shots in my hotel room and keep the good ones. Nothing is posted on social media, every photo I take is only for myself to look back to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2407490
I’ve almost never taken video apart from some underwater stuff with a GoPro that my wife and I bought on a whim to take snorkeling with us; she loves reefs and fish. I take a small number of phone snapshots when I travel, mostly to share pictures of my kids with their grandparents, who live in another country and rarely see them. I also take local snapshots for a personal blog that I don’t advertise or share with anyone apart from a small handful of friends and family members—it’s a purely personal project, not something I’m trying to make money off of or use to get famous.

I do have a “real” camera, but it’s bulky and expensive and I rarely use it; I like taking wildlife photographs when I can, along with occasional street scenes or landscapes from unusually photogenic places.

>manage to get there with still plenty of time by some miracle.
>there is a little building there that organises the buses
>but they say the real location where the buses depart from is way outside the city
>a minibus just takes you from this place to the real bus station

These threads generally go to shit the second /biz/ shows up or /pol/; hell both are dumb enough in these threads. This is generally because this board and most people completely miss the mark as to what Digital Nomad entails in the day to day.

>what people actually believe
Sit on the beach drinking with 3.14 qt girls around you partying each night after sending an email and using haxx0r level wpm on the keyboard to do all coding in <15 minutes for the month
>what it actually is
1. Booking a decent hotel or airbnb with good internet to take calls at possibly odd hours
2. Lining up free time and PTO to allow you to have a proper weekend for events
3. Spend more of your free time learning tricks to automate your job better
4. Keeping a close eye on your projects and work, making sure no one could tell if you were in or out of the office or "wfh" location

It's rewarding if you can self manage and plan your time and works best in administrative or task oriented positions like IT/programming/etc. If you can't find plenty of spare time in your WFH job today don't bother doing a DN adventure, you'll just piss yourself off and end up burned out within 3 months of it.

I lived in Chongqing and Xi'an. There are barely any white people in these cities. Sometimes I would have to go to smaller cities for extra work. During the winter and summer holidays (where I got like two months off) I would visit as many places as possible.
>what about foreigner prices?
there are so few foreigners in China that this barely even exists as a concept. 20 years ago it did but most Chinese dont see white people are rich anymore. They'll just charge you the normal price. In the REALLY touristy areas of Shanghai or Beijing this probably happens but I dont know as I dont really go to those places. In BJ I went to some super touristy markets cause my mom came to visit me but it all turned out fine. There are some old granny markets you can go to where you are suppose to bargain with them, but I doubt the average tourist will go to these places.
>you skipped the morning markets
My life was all about the markets. You seriously think they are going to overcharge me for jianbing when all the prices are on signs? After 1 year living there you start to get a feel for what the prices are and I never felt taken advantage of. You have to be a true top tier idiot to fall for any scams because they are obvious as fuck. The scams you'll encounter are beautiful girls on Tantan asking you to meet them but you have to pay for their taxi, Shanghai taxis or buying a "Chamel" bag/perfume from some street vendor thinking its legit. The only real worries I had in China were about air quality as eastern coastal cities moved all their factories inland making Chengdu and Chongqing air pollution shitholes (though if you want to visit BJ and Shanghai you'll be pleasantly surprised about how good the air is now) also you have to be aware of the bad food quality in China. While the gutter oil problem is overstated, it hasn't been completely eradicated either.

I've been on that exact ship twice.
One other time on Harmony, which is a sister ship.
Cruises are by far the best way to do a vacation.
Pay a set price, about $1,000pp/pw often less.
That's it. It's all included. Drinks, food, alcohol, entertainment. It's all there and included.
You get to relax, eat some of the best food you will ever fucking have, and visit a new country every day.

The ships themselves are something else.
The Oasis class, which Wonder is part of, has literal fucking parks inside them.

I've been on 6 cruises total, and always had a good time.

If you ever wanted to go on one, do it.

Just don't cheap out and go with some jew cruise line.

Royal Caribbean, NCL, and Virgin are the best for the average person.
Celebrity, Viking, and Princess are nice but high-end. Like, you need to dress nice high-end.
Disney if you have kids.
Fuck any other cruise line. Especially Carnival.

>>2405629
>what country's nature impressed you

never really traveled much in other countries, but Hawaii impressed the hell out of me.

I went for a 10 day vacation, split between Maui and Kauai, and found it to be literal heaven on Earth.

Everything you expect from Hawaii is exactly what it is. The weather, the beaches, the forests and jungles, the rivers...

it felt to me like the cleanest outdoor experience i've ever encountered. In other places I've been, going to the river or beach can be a somewhat dirty and miserable experience, if you get wet you feel like shit. In Hawaii? You don't even really need a towel while exploring. You just dry off in like 10 minutes.

It's strikingly beautiful in every way. The air is cleaner than what continental Americans are accustomed to, the water is more pleasant, the people are far nicer. Honestly felt like every single person we met while traveling wanted us to have a fantastic time.

Do you plan to have an income during your two nomadic years? Have you graduated university or some kind of training program, or have plans to do something like that when you return?
If I was in your position, I'd be very tempted to travel around for a couple of years and enjoy life. And I won't try to dissuade you because I'd probably still do it. My suggestions are to set a monthly budget for yourself (or a longer time frame budget if you're going to different CoL countries) and have a plan for what you're going to do when you return. You don't want to burn through your money and come back and have no realistic plan to get more money/earn a living.
Don't rely on the idea your parents/family will be there to bail you out and let you move back home and eat their meals without paying anything. A lot can change in the two years you're gone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405436
Stay in hostels, it's simply the easiest way to make a good trip a great trip.
You will meet a ton of people in them, often you can ask them about places to go or sometimes people will just invite you to places. Don't listen to the myths about hostels only being for hippy stoners or weird old guys; there's all sorts of people in them and that is part of the fun, I have met full time investors and people that are travelling to play in gaming competitions on my trips. staying around new people will also improve your social skills immensely which a lot of people on this website can do with.
On the other hand not all hostels are made equal, some are small and quiet and some are huge and never stop the music, I prefer something in the middle so read the reviews before booking.

>What to pack
Clothing obviously depends on location (do you really need a down jacket in the tropics?) but typically bring enough clothes for like 5 or 6 days. Other countries wash their clothes too, and in a pinch, washing your clothes in the sink or shower is totally fine.
Leave the nintendo switch and the ipad at home. Your phone is enough and if you're going for a long time or maybe working while traveling, a small laptop. Power adapter and phone battery pack are a must.

>Luggage
Skip the wheeled suitcases, they WILL become cumbersome and annoying, use only a backpack. Put some other personal bag in your backpack like a tote bag or sling for you to use daily. Osprey has a good range of backpacks, if you are only travelling for a couple weeks than carry-on only is totally possible, otherwise a slightly larger bag may be needed.

>Websites
Booking for accomodation
Rome2Rio for transport
SkyScanner for flights

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2407178
My other tips

-Be spontaneous. If someone invites you to do something cool, you should probably do it even if you didn't have it in your plans.
-Don't try to do too much, a lot of people have this problem and try to cram all of Europe into a 2 week trip.
-Keep a low profile, avoid standing out too much. Especially in more conservative countries like the middle east or japan, don't be the "loudmouth westerner" just smile and be polite. Don't be too loud and annoy locals, they will like you more.
-Do local things such as use public transport, eat local foods, go to the supermarket. I really enjoy going to the supermarket and buying some food and making my own meals, it helps me save money and eating out at restaurants every meal gets tiring.
-If you like saving money, look for overnight transport options. Overnight buses or boats are common in many countries and get you accommodation and transport in 1.
-Don't be a picky eater, if you are just know that I have a very low opinion of you.

>>2400999
Personally I gotta say I didn't really like Medellin itself all that much because of the striking contrast of poverty everywhere in the city. Like, you go to Plaza Botero and it's so full of homelessness and streetwalking prostitutes it was rather shocking. Even around El Poblado I found plenty of unsavory characters and I honestly felt like I could be robbed at any moment.
The highlights of the trip to Medellin were the times I wasn't in Medellin itself. Guatape, Jardin, Santa Fe de Antioquia were so much better. Mind you, I'm not really a party person, so my opinion doesn't account for that kind of stuff.
Medellin does have a bunch of cool viewpoints as it's in a valley surrounded by mountains, I would recommend trying going up Cerro Pan de Azucar - easy to get to via metrocable, some 45 minutes of walking and you're on top, the walk didn't feel unsafe either and there were plenty of people chilling on top (pic related). Mirador el Cielo is also pretty good.
Didn't to the comuna 13 tour but I heard good things about it.

>>2401084
El poblado is full of expats and backpackers and is entirely skippable if you're looking for an experience that doesn't involve acai bowls and overpriced beer. La setenta in laureles is a better nightlife.

Other medellin recommendations would be casa de la memoria and cerro de las tres cruces. My preffered bandeja paisa are la gloria de la gloria (envigado) and hacienda (near plaza botero).

Communa 13 is meh. Its become quite commercialised post-pandemic, but same with el peñol in guatape. Speaking of guatape, nearby San Rafael has good Charcos to take a dip in, although it would be a full day to do both.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405827
Hundred yen stores. By the way, you'll need to use the Japan post website to print out a shipping label because Japan will not just let you write the address on the box anymore. You can print out the label at a convenience store. They have photocopy machines. And when you fill out the info you have to be exact on the weight and describing the contents. If you just describe it as "toy" or "collectable" they'll tell you to go and do the entire process all over again. So make sure you weigh it, describe it as "super embarassing creepy anime bullshit," and put the monetary value on the insurance claim form. Set aside a few hours to do all this and never use Japan post again.

An update from the last thread in regards to the Platt Kotodama train.

I tried to get a ticket but its the same price as a regular Shinkansen ticket. The only difference now is that its an hour slower and stops at more places. So if you are going from Tokyo to Osaka, your options are Shinkansen as most expensive but easiest. Domestic flight thats less time in a chair and cheaper but requires more logistics, or theres the night bus which is the cheapest, slowest option. The sleeper train really only seems like an option if you just really want to experience it or you need an overnight when planes or trains arent running and maybe cant or wont take the bus.

Lawsons can get expensive so keep an eye on spending even if it's convenient
Pregame with strong 0's or liquor before a bar
Never take a taxi
Use day passes when possible

If solo, not ok with hostels and you are getting JR pass, you will have to be careful of your spending.

It's easy to eat quite decently off 1500-2000yen, its easy to sleep off 3000-4000yen (thats hostel if solo, or split cost of hotel/airbnb for non solo), travel per regular day at 600yen. That puts you at like 95k for the 14 days averaging the high numbers here, or like 80k at low numbers.
~30kyen JR pass puts you over in either option, so could consider overnight bus to osaka (and back) as its the travel and a nights accommodation cost. Gives you a decent chunk extra change in the pocket.

Accommodation requirements will likely be biggest factor here, if you are chill with cheap hostels, it could give you a bit of breathing room in the budget. Next biggest being that JR pass vs other travel methods.
So look up some accommodation for your dates to get an idea there and fill in your cost alongside the other numbers here

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just did a week in Zermatt for a snowboard trip. It was the most expensive place I have ever been in my entire life, and also one of the most beautiful. As others said, the food is definitely not as good as France and Italy. Nearly everyone we met was a tourist or a seasonal worker from some other country. The Matterhorn and the surrounding mountains are unreal. It was cold as shit the week we were there, but the snow was good. The ski trails were too difficult for my wife, but I had a good time. The town is pristine. Every spot in town looks like a postcard.

Would I recommend visiting? Yes...but only if you have plenty of money saved up for the trip. We never ate out once for less than $100. We spent $400 for 2 roundtrip train tickets from Geneva to Zermatt. Snowboard and boot rental were $100 per day, not including the lift ticket. We ran into tourists from South America who couldn't afford to get a beer in the bars because they were $12.
If I ever go back, it'll be in the summer. If I snowboard again in Europe, it'll be on the French or Italian side, or possibly in Slovenia.

>>2406382
I never crossed over into Italy when I was boarding, but it was open. It was insanely cold that week and I didn't want to risk getting stuck on the Italian side with my wife back in Zermatt. It was -17 C on the mountain all week.

Renting snowboarding gear outside of Zermatt and hauling it on the train would have been really inconvenient. We saw other people doing it and it looked terrible. Hauling that shit on the train would not have been worth the $100 we would have saved. The best thing about Zermatt is that you don't wait in line for snowboarding. We never waited for a single person to board a gondola or eat out anywhere. The photo looks crowded because that was where everyone stopped to take photos on the mountain. The run from the top was 14 miles. There were sections where I wouldn't see anyone else for 10 minutes.

The mountain infrastructure in Switzerland is incredible. Every peak has a giant gondola. Zermatt had a train and a gondola that takes you to the top. The train system wasn't as fast as Italy, but they were really nice and never very crowded. The train route from Geneva to Zermatt was amazing. The views are insane.

>>2406435
Sure. You could save money and not eat out, or stay in a smaller place, but why go to Switzerland then? If you're in a budget, go to the Alps in France or Italy. We had a huge Airbnb in the middle of Zermatt that was the entire third floor of a building. It was $200 a night. not cheap, but way better than the tony hotel rooms in town that were same price or more. We did stay in a hotel for 2 nights in Geneva. Switzerland has the smallest hotel rooms I've ever seen. I also think it's fair to mention that a fondue meal for 2 in Switzerland at a decent restaurant is going to run you $150. Or that bars charge $18+ for a mixed drink. I bought a couple $25 Mai Tais at the Grand Hotel that were worth every penny.

posts.com: Retard here. Let’s say I want to sleep at a hotel starting Sunday night but I’m leaving the hotel Wednesday morning, do I book Sunday to Tuesday?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: No, you typically book hotels "per night" so that would be Sunday, Monday and Tuesday night, meaning you would check out Wednesday morning. So the booking would say Sunday-Wednesday.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You're paying per night so, hypothetical scenario (4pm check-in time/11am checkout time assuming)

Sunday 4pm/Monday morning is a night
Monday 4pm/Tuesday morning is night
Tuesday 4pm/Wednesday 11am is the third night

Sunday 4pm-Wednesday 11am, three nights

I live in San Diego also. You can get a FLIGHT from Tijuana to Mexico City for under $100 round trip, booked in advance. Buses aren't much cheaper. Why would you take the bus? Unless its for the meme. It'll take days. There's a bus to La Paz & Cabo too, its about 24 hours straight from TJ.

You should be able to get decent meals at inexpensive local places for under 100 pesos/person. Along with the usual tacos and shit look for places that advertise "comida corrida" which is a lunch special with a fixed item that is usually cheap, meant for people who are on a lunch break. This is especially true the further you get from the US, goods and services get cheaper. You should be able to get decent, but not touristy hotels for $25-50/night in areas that are safe/on major routes but not "touristy." Hostels aren't super common but there are some in more touristy cities. There's also pensiones which is like a hostel style bed in a room (shared bathrooms) which should be under $20. Hotels may or may not have internet and it may or may not be fast. Mexico still has a culture of internet cafes, these will probably be full of kids playing online games but more places have internet now than 10 years ago when it was still rare.

I'm really surprised how few people here visit Mexico.

anyone travelled on cruise ships?
how are they these days
>>boomers?
>>sloots
>>boat tech

can anyone give a qrd

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They're all inclusive resorts on the sea. The larger modern ships have an insane amount in them. They're comparable to Holiday camps like Butlins but I think those are UK only things so that may not be especially helpful.

Cruises in general skew older but Disney Cruises (and cheap line) trend towards families, Cunard trend to have the oldest people (and are more formal), Virgin are aimed at young couples (and being "not like other cruises"). Sex cruises will be full of old swingers or be gay focused. Lots of people go on cruises to make friends so if you're sociable and are able to strike up conversations you can end up finding a couple/group/family to enjoy it with. Some cruise lines offer Solo cruise matching facilities where you share a cabin with someone they think you'll get on with (not a hook up).

Day trips only show you a very limited amount of a location so try to avoid big city wide tours (you'll whizz through everything) and aim for more focused ones that are on one particular activity/location. Glacier focused cruises are very popular because of how suited they are to this (NCL is the company for those).

Most popular types:

>glacier
>European cities
>Caribbean beach cruises

Repositioning cruises are the ones to go for if you're looking for a cheap holiday that's focused on being on the boat. There are also cruises to nowhere that often happen when a new ship launches. Tend to be cheaper for solo cruises too.

Transatlantic boats are very different from coastal boats as they're designed for the rougher seas. Be very careful of getting a Europe to America cruise on a boat that isn't meant for transatlantic trips.

>>2402209
You pretty much described Nice and the surrounding area (Cannes, Antibes etc, basically the French Riviera and the "arrière-pays niçois").
Not the cheapest area of France, possibly one of the most expensive ones but nowhere as crazy as Paris, especially if you're not after some nice house with a view over the sea.
It has mountains within 20 minutes of driving, and 1.5-2 hours takes you to ski stations and national parks (and there are buses taking you there).
It's right next to Northern Italy, the climate is absolutely great most of the year.
There's nice architecture in the area, more job opportunities than in many areas of France, population is quite young as young people from all over France come work here.
Yes, it can get expensive, but it's still cheaper than Paris and it's still ok to live there if you don't get too close to the sea. The further you are from the sea, the cheaper it is.

>>2402209
You might consider Toulouse as well. It's the fourth largest city in the country (after Paris, Lyon, and Marseille). It's what passes for a tech hub in France, with AirBus and some startups around to provide jobs. It's a university town, so it has a very active nightlife. The bars around the Place Saint-Pierre are always PACKED, especially Chez Tonton (even on weekdays). Le Saint des Seins is also worth checking out, though that one only gets busy on weekends.

Rents are cheap, the climate is very good since the city is so far south. The only downside I can think of is the fact that it's so far inland. But there's lakes and shit you can do a day trip to in the summer.

Unfortunately, there's many blacks, but that can't be helped these days when it comes to France. It didn't seem as bad as other cities, though.

Pic related, a summer night along the Garonne

They have a fair amount of tourism, but it didn't strike me as an expat city in particular. Most of those types go off to Madrid, being the capital, or Barcelona. IIRC the houses are more affordable too. It still has some edgy shit like crappy 'ANTIFA ZONE' graffiti, but in reality most people are extremely chill. Never had any crime issues or felt unsafe. There's stuff open until very late in the night. Even very late I'd sometimes see families. It's a beautiful city, but much like the rest of Spain it very ugly modern civil architecture (France and Italy have their share too, but Spain is arguably dogshit when it comes to this). There's lots of smaller towns nearby which are cosy for a visit or possibly work out as a home too. Sagunto in particular. Albaraccin is one of the best places for bouldering in the world, and it is close by. The metro is cheap and covers pretty much covers most of the city. Maybe rent an Airbnb for a month and see how you find it? Then check out different suburbs, etc. I rented a small studio flat in the city center for 540 + bills, and split it with my ex. So we ended up paying each like 300€ per month.

Regarding hotels, among the common brands, Ibis Styles seems to be the cheapest, which is still relatively expensive for the long term (ca. 80$ per night).

>The only problem I have it's extremely hard to rent an ordinary apartment without having a French job, bank and/or guarantor.
You can try Facebook groups for expats or apartments in the area. I've run into people willing to rent to me under the table this way. They save on taxes, so it's win-win.

It'll be an uphill battle though, because French landlords are jumpy about renting to those who aren't copacetic. This is because they have the most retarded squatting laws in the world. Niggers break into boomers' houses while they're on vacation. By the time they arrive, they've been around for a month, so they can't be evicted. The owner has to initiate a legal process that could last years to get his own property back.

Make sure your online presence isn't dodgy before you reach out to people looking for a place to stay. You'll end up paying for the low-trust environment one way or another, either by paying more or paying upfront. I don't think there's anything you can do about that, I'm afraid. Even on AirBnB, some boomer bitch cancelled my stay because I didn't have any reviews.

Whenever I visit my gf who lives in Cannes, I always liked going to Mougins. There’s nothing much apart from restaurants, parks and a nice village centre but it’s just nice to look at. The whole area is nice. There are some towns to avoid such as Vallauris because it’s full of immigrants but if you drive through you won’t notice much, as the ols buildings are still pretty to look at.

Honestly, what I love the most about the area is basically all the Pré-Alpes area right next to Cannes; it’s basically a mountainous zone but not crazy high with easy access. Villages like Andon, Saint Cesaire sur Siagne etc are just so nice.

Then if you go further up behind Nice, towards Mercantour, it’s another deal. It’s called the arrière-pays niçois and yeah, you get real mountains and you basically have alpine villages, but southern french/northern italian style. Very charming and extremely safe. Immigrants hate mountains.

I can tell you right now sri lanka is absolutely stunning, and an amazing place to visit. It has a very rich history, culture and beautiful landscapes.

It's also by far the cleanest country in South Asia.

Essentially the country has been coloninized three times by the Dutch, Portuguese and British. Each leaving behind their own piece of history.

Before that, in the 9th century, the country served as an Arab trade outpost/halfway point to South East Asia. There are still tons of Muslim architecture to see and the population is around 10% Muslim.

Even before that, there are thousands of years old fortresses such as The Lion Fortress of previous kingdoms.

The people are also super friendly, and very attuned to foreigners.

Also it's hella cheap. Not sure about right now given the economic crises, but it should still be fine.

The beaches, especially on the east coast are amazing. One of the best places in the world to see blue whales as well.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
Dear /trv/eterans,

I have decided to create a thread for those interested in general information regarding living abroad. I think a lot of threads tend to discuss some singular aspects of living in certain countries, but I feel like regrouping these, no matter if they're country-specific or not, would be worth it, for the sake of archiving interesting information within one single (or a series of thread). This thread is aimed at prospecting beginners.

>Why should I live abroad ?
Many reasons. Cost of life can be better abroad, job opportunities more favorable to your field of work, a society you're more in tune with (safety, values). Other possibilities include doing an academic exchange or a double diploma, maybe an internship of some kind that will enhance your CV to prospective recruiters from your home country (or the one you want to go to.)

>But I don't want to live there forever !
It's fine, most people don't and leave after a few years. You don't have to marry a local, buy a house and stay there forever. Sometimes it's nice to go out there, take it out of your system, then come back all grown up and with some new tricks up your sleeve.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>What do you mean by that ? What do I gain from doing a temporary expatriation?
It really depends on how fruitful it was, but aside from whatever professional experience you've gain from it, by doing you so you have learned to leave your comfort zone, forced yourself into socializing with people who had no reason to talk to you besides speaking English and probably befriended some, negotiated for jobs and deals with people that are completely foreign to you and learned what it truly meant to be alone and be your own island, sometimes. If you came to say, Asia, with nothing more than a high school degree and nothing else but your hands, you've also learned how to network, find a job, and to pay your bills you actually had to learn how to keep that job. Of course, perhaps the conditions that made you get the job in the first place won't be there at home, which will make you stay. But at least you're actually functional now. And you'll be able to figure something out.

>Is immigration/expatriation something I should prepare ?
The more you prepare it, the better. Learning the local language (not necessarily bilingual but every bit helps), acquiring a skill, gathering information on how to get in and what visa schemes are available for you are all too important parts of a successful experience abroad.

>why the tripcode ?
Because I won't LARP. The answer you will receive from me will either be something I know to be true from personal experience. And the tripcode ensures that if I truly am bullshitting you, I can get called out for everything i've said throughout the series of threads that will be posted. It's a win-win.

And with that, the thread begins. If you're experienced, don't hesitate to share your experiences, tips and tricks you know. If you're not, don't hesitate to ask all the questions you want to ask.
P.S : human trafficking solliciters, remember that you're violating US law.

No problem. I'm only talking about Taiwan because that's what I know, and you seem to have either Taiwan or Japan as an endgoal. You won't solve being a shut-in by meeting up open people. You'll solve it by either meeting people who match your energy or truly learning why you can't socialize.

Introverts don't want to talk shop because they think small talk is a thing for retards, when really, small talk is the human way to show that they want to sniff your butt and enter your social circle so they can actually open up to you. Ironically, go really autistic and try to get into deep shit with them and they fucking freak out like anybody else because that's not what normally constituted people do, so damned if you do, and damned if you don't. Other things being invited to go have a meal with a group or with a friend and often refusing, which people understand as a rejection of friendship and not just a circumstantial thing, if repeated more than once.
It doesn't matter where you go, this is true everywhere.

>Are people open to be my friends ?
Since you said you were autistic, i'll tell you how it goes. In general, most people, Taiwanese included, are open to be your friend, provided you have some kind of pretext to meet them. If you don't know anybody, are not partaking in any hobbies and do not have a job yet, why would a perfect stranger befriend you ? Think about this problem, and trying to find some solutions on your own would be a good exercise.

Second, I always recommend people to go out and meet the expats in Taipei. They're a varied, decent bunch, very open, and are present in pretty much every night scene, they understand what it is to be a complete stranger to everyone and having to spontaneously meet new folks, and until you can understand how to make friends with locals, they can also introduce you to some. Internet people (not just 4chan) pretend they snob them but it's really that they've never talked to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391118
>>2391118
People always say it's the best way but the way it happens makes it so that it basically never does. MNCs function in such a way that every national branch is its own company. They bill shit to each other, and either compete with, or work in fields that aren't quite the ones back home.

For example, a lot of MNCs will have folks working sales abroad to sell the products produced back home. And the people they will hire are obviously locals because they might be cheaper or just more at ease with communicating with the locals. Also, hiring an equivalent foreign worker is pound to pound as skilled as a local is considered bad practice and is starting to get heavily curbed in Asia.

Therefore, differentiation is key. Differentiation through diplomas (Prestigious ones), differentiation through specialization (PhDs in certain fields of expertise that are needed there, for example, or at least +5 year in a field but more is better).

If you're ballsy enough you can point out a certain need in a foreign branch, explain how to fill it so they can tailor a job offer for you there, too.
This being said, a lot of people manage to get to work abroad if they have +5 years exp in dev, sometimes less. Foreign internships, exchanges and double diplomas during your studies can help if you take the necessary steps professionally to make it work.

In a nutshell, anything that makes you a better person than a local works. And that also goes by evening the playing fields. Some countries have visa schemes that facilitate foreign hiring for skilled workers. Speaking the local language in a professional capacity also helps leveling the playing field and beating other foreign contenders. Again, you don't necessarily need to do all that to try your luck. But I suggest you orient yourself by tailoring yourself to be a competitive foreign worker as you go, which will only better your odds. Also, seriously, the field. Don't go to china with a pol sci degree.

posts.name: Tolstoi

>>2391264
Alternatively, just take some time there to look for ways to find a job.

Singapore allows you to look for a job on a tourist visa. Save up, and you can defintiely find a private room for around 1k a month, possibly cheaper in Singapore (I am looking at this semester's Airbnb offers to make sure), and all you really need is just one room, one bathroom, and enough place for your clothes (possibly two suits for job interviews), and an internet connection. You could possibly stay more to maximize your chances and enlarge the window of opportunities. Of course, don't just go there without any clue. Apply for job offers, make sure you mention that you will be available for an interview during said time period, and see what gives. No need to go for a month if you've only got one offer.

I believe in the material, meat and potatoes. I am interested in the things that I know will bring me happiness. Call me a hedonist if you want, but I refuse to do things that will, further down the line, only bring me depression, contempt for other people, and spend my precious life on this earth.
If there is a more gratifying job, a better partner to be with, a better place to be in, i'll go right there and I see no reason to deprive myself of anything that could be a step up. An argument can be made about what makes it truly a step-up, sure, but it is undeniable that for some people in certain countries, you can really improve your life by going abroad. I actually believe that a temporary experience (which is what an expatriation is, by the way) is nice to have. Discovering foreign cultures in an in-depth way is a life-changing experience and it doesn't have to be a permanent one.

Also, just because you have less value in your country doesn't mean that this value is inherent to you. Maybe being an introverted engineer in a western country that has abandoned its industrial sector translates to being a polite, at ease socially engineer in Taiwan's booming industry ? Maybe being a French chef in France is hardly well paid and recognized because we've got so many of them, but it translates to being a great chef abroad with very interesting and classy recipes ?
In other words, why should an Eskimo who failed at selling popsicles in Alaska be called a failure because he decided to try his luck in Malaysia where the weather's too fucking hot all year around ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395192
>I thought increasingly in asia you require a degree level in whatever to qualify for English teaching at least I thought that was the case in China and Japan.
That is increasingly, and indeed, nearly always the case, and not just in China and Japan. Thailand requires degrees too, has done for years now.

People without degrees but with certifications can still sometimes find work in Thailand, typically either as private tutors or at the sleaziest of private language school sweatshops, but they can’t get work permits or non-immigrant visa sponsorship. So the work (and as often as not, the teachers’ residence) is under the table and officially illegal, with all the risk that implies. It’s been a few years since the last crackdown, but Thai authorities have caught and mass deported English teachers working without proper papers several times that I can remember.

The only place I’ve ever personally known someone to work full-time as a teacher without a degree was Cambodia, but there may be other Wild West possibilities out there.

Still almost certain to run into visa/permit problems, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: how do you find a job abroad? im a young engineer and id like to work in asia for a few years, im a bit clueless on how to find a job postings. i just tried linked in and some googling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395792
Linkedin, indeed. Check on the internet where do people post their job postings for a particular country. Get yourself some letters of recommendation. References are also ok but since some employers might not care since they can't really believe them, having some letters right off the bat can be a plus for these cases.
Possibly translate your CV.

If a country seriously strikes your fancy, you could try to go there for a week or two with the sole goal of networking. Meet literally anyone with the largest common denominator, aka alumnis, then dudes in your field you might meet in expat bars that are from your home country, and just ask around for pointers and tips (never directly for a job). Also, read up on this process of networking so you don't sound like a scummy hustler.


Add a lot of recruiters on linkedin from the particular country in the companies that interest you.

If you can arrange some interviews before your trip do so and make sure you specify the time period at which you will be present.

Finally, one of the bigger reason people struggle is because they either do not have enough experience , or they're not specialists in a field the local job market is interested in.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>>2395891
No one ever said it to be easy. It's hard and it requires foresight and preparation. Even the MNC route isn't granted.
But it happens. People every year manage to succeed in doing that, and fortune usually favors the bold. If all you do is sit down in the comfort of your home and job and apply for job postings abroad with a foreign address, unwilling to do your interviews physically, with little to no investment in staying by forcing into others the fact that you speak english and the unwillingness of doing nothing else, there is literally no reason why they should hire you.
Not only sponsoring a visa can be a pain in the ass to the HR, you going there and realizing you didn't like the place and leaving after a year makes it so not worth it for them to even consider you.

You should also compensate for the difficulty of the endeavor with a good enough volume. If you're looking to go to Taiwan, do them all-Taiwan, Japan, Korea, China, HK and Singapore. Even the ones you don't want -who cares ? My friend who was in a situation similar to yours, applied to around 500 offers over the course of a year and got around 5 interviews, 2 of which resulted in a "yes".

Another had literally no fucking experience whatsoever but just happened to save some money and went on a 2 month trip in Taiwan after college to celebrate. My man had a job lined up by the end of the first month. That guy was smart however, had the great idea of hiring a professional translator to rigorously translate his CV and cover letter, and the guy just played up to the HRs.

As for me, the reason why i'm here is because i've literally tailored my studies to finding a job there.Double diplomas, internships... There's a lot of things you can do to get yourself wherever you want provided you think about it soon enough.

Ironically, the best country you could move to to buy a home would be your own country, for legal reasons. The next best thing is Western Europe for the same reasons.

I think the Côte de Provence would be a great place. It is very quiet, very sunny, lots of trails and hiking, beaches and palm trees all over the coast. There's a good reason why so many americans buy property there. Other areas would include the Andalucian coast in Spain, too. If you're ballsy enough, you could try Morocco I guess. Places like this could get you a relatively nice house between 300 and 200k and a really good one at 500k, maybe get a small car for easy commuting and that's it, you're set for life, maybe get a TEFL cert and here you go.

Just make sure you live in the suburbs. avoid the big cities such as Marseille, Montpellier and Nice. You want nice and tranquil and safe, the suburbs of the mediterranean coast will be perfect for you.

Also, don't listen to the people who'll say the contrary. They're probably French and they suck at comparing since they have no experience of anything else.

Gay Area is the most New Yorky part of the country outside NY. Peninsula is like Long Island. North Bay is like Conneticut. East Bay is like Queens and Brooklyn. South Bay is like New Jersey. It's like NY but prettier, warmer, more mountainous, the pizza sucks and people can't take a joke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Depends on the weather. If it's nice and sunny, take the ferry across to Angel Island and rent some bikes and do the loop. The views are amazing and the bike trail is awesome.

The Musée Mécanique at Fisherman's Wharf is good, but don't eat around there.

The Sutro Baths are cool.

If you want to do a cool waterfall hike, go check out Cataract Falls. It's a tough uphill hike, but a really gorgeous forest with giant redwood trees and a lake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: if youre gonna actually be in San Jose/south to east bay: mission peak is a nice hike where you can see a pretty view of the bay at the top. coyote hills has a nice overlook of the water but it might be a little stinky. downtown SJ is super nostalgic to me and has an art museum. banana leaf in fremont is a good malaysian place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2405023
go to the santa cruz beach boardwalk.
spend an afternoon walking down the embarcadero in sf. start at the ferry plaza building visiting the market inside.
visit cannery row and monterey.
considering napa is near by, try local wine if you're into that. there's also some amazing breweries - fieldwork being one of the best.
asian and indian food is amazing in the bay, but it's probably just as good in ny.

if you're staying in san jose - check out san pedro market for dinner. south 1st street also has some nice places to eat. get a burrito from la victoria or iguanas and always ask for extra orange sauce. camino and happas are the best breweries imo.

oh and in & out burger just to say you've been.

these are all basic recommendations from a local. a bit touristy, but being that your only staying for a week i'd say this would give a good experience at the very least.

The views as you ascend through the forests to the dessert landscape at the base of El Tiede is insane. The brakes in all the rental cars are cooked to fuck because it requires serious braking stresses coming back down to sea level.

Most beaches are small and rocky but I don't care for beaches anyway.

>>2404226
I've only been to Lanzarote but I absolutely loved it. Beautiful beaches, but the interior is even cooler. Parque Nacional de Timanfaya is cool as shit and absolutely worth, basically there was a giant eruption in the 1700s that buried multiple villages and covered the entire interior of the island with lava. Very very cool. Lots of art by a guy named Cesar Manrique, really cool houses and a cactus park. Unique wine region as the volcanic soil has special properties, very much worth visiting a winery and seeing how they do it - basically they grow grapes with a wall of pumice stone behind them which siphon the moisture out of the wind, since it's so dry there. The entire island is basically a giant desert covered in lava.

All that to say it's very cool, one of the most unique places I've ever been, kinda like a Spanish Hawaii. I haven't been to any of the other islands so can't compare but I would absolutely go back to las Canarias to see how they compare to Lanzarote. It's a very unique place with a lot of cool cultural stuff and history. Honestly could be its own country, it's that different from the mainland.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I recently spent 3 weeks in Iraq, both north and south. Some pertinent info and thoughts if you're looking to do the same.

Entry + visa - I entered Iraq through the land border with Kuwait which you, if you know about Kuwait, will not be surprised to learn was a fucking hassle. Internet says there's a public bus that runs to the border but there isn't, the only option is a taxi. I got to the border and learnt that I needed a green piece of paper from the ministry of interior authorising me to leave Kuwait to Iraq via land, and that I could only get it from the office back in the city. This wasted an entire day, as the office was closed by the time I got back to the city. I got it the next morning from the interior office next to the airport - it only took 5 minutes and didn't cost anything. Back at the border, crossing is fairly straight forward. The Iraqi side is underdeveloped and pretty dusty. Visa on arrival for all the good western passports is available at all ports of entry and cost me $77USD, and was issued surprisingly quickly. From the border town of Safwan, you'll probably take a cab to Basra. I went straight to Baghdad from the Basra taxi station, about a 6 hour drive. I imagine flying into Baghdad is far more straightforward.

Baghdad - a surprisingly nice city compared to what you may think. Much nicer than Cairo, I thought, and enough to keep you busy for up to a week, although 4 days would be fine. My favourite thing to do was strolling through Mutannabi street and the adjacent areas where the local craftsmen, book sellers, and antique dealers are. The mosques around this area are stunning and will give you a good sense of the distinct architectural style of Baghdad, i.e. intricate brickwork and blue and yellow domes. If you like modern stuff like malls, chic cafes etc then Mansour area is very nice. Museums, monuments, mosques (go to kadhimiya) and food are plentiful and will keep you busy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402967
Liquor shops are present and openly advertised. Women dress anywhere from jeans and tees to the full burqa. Careem works everywhere in Baghdad and is very convenient, as navigating the local minivans would be practically impossible without being a local. Traffic is standard developing-world-tier, frustrating but inevitable. Airbnbs are basically non-existent everywhere in Iraq and so I ended up staying in budget hotels. In Baghdad, the cheap ones (~25USD per night) can be found in the bataween area. Quality tends to be pretty shit, but if you just want a bed, it's fine. I stayed in Hotel Diwan. Baghdad feels safe enough and not tense, but keep your head on a swivel anyway. Standard precautions, don't walk late at night, dress conspicuously, speak a bit of arabic.

Karbala and Najaf - the two holjest Shia sites in Iraq, along with kadhimiya in Baghdad and Askari in Samarra. Both fairly well developed (relative to the region) due to the number of pilgrims. Go to either one first depending on your itinerary, and get there from the Al alawi south garage in Baghdad. You can take a bus or shared taxi, and the same for the next city. Hotel situation is much the same as above. 1-2 full days in each is appropriate, because all there really is to see are the shrines. Great places to learn about shia Islam and meet people from all over the world. People tend to be friendly here and strike up conversation, ask where you're from etc. No issue saying that you're not Muslim, just follow the customs that will be very evident and displayed on the entrances to the shrines. Shrines are open 24/7 and you can even sleep in them if you're so inclined.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402967
People tend to be quite fair in Iraq and I didn't really experience anyone trying to charge me the standard yt prices, though this could be because lots of people assumed I'm Lebanese or because I can speak enough rubbish arabic to make any given vendor smile. The average Iraqi is very happy to welcome guests, though, and I had people offer to pay for my meals on several occasions when they learnt I was foreign.

Babylon - a day trip from karbala. Most disappointing thing I visited in Iraq desu. Site was all but abandoned apart from one guard sitting on a plastic chair, and the entrance fee for foreigners is 25k dinars (~18USD), which is absurd for Iraq. Just a bunch of brick walls with no explanatory signage or context. Might as well have been waking in any given field. The blue gate is cool I suppose but isn't the original one, that's in Berlin. Worth going, though, to visit Saddam's palace that's on the hill overlooking the city.

Samarra - 2 hour shared taxi from Baghdad, Al alawi north garage. Samarra isn't controlled by the fed gov and is instead run by a Shia militia called the peace companies. You'll get stopped at the checkpoint before the entrance to the city and made to hand over your passport to them. Your shared taxi, presumably filled with locals, will be told to continue and you'll be kept at the checkpoint where they'll call some local driver and assign him to you for the day. Westerners aren't allowed to stay overnight in Samarra, and apparently the security situation is still quite tenuous there. It's a shithole anyway, the only two things to see are malwiya mosque, the big spiral minaret, and Askari shrine. Your assigned driver probably knows you're there to see them anyway and will take you there and back to the checkpoint where you'll collect your passport. Malwiya is cool, but again is 25k for yt. Askari is free, and worth seeing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402967
Mosul - one of the most surreal places I've ever seen. 5hr shared taxi from Baghdad north, again, or you could continue on from samarra I guess. There isn't a whole lot going on in mosul in the normal sense, but walking around the rubble of the old city is unreal, as is meeting locals and hearing their stories about life under Isis. See if you can co-ordinate permissions with UNESCO to visit Al Nuri mosque which is being reconstructed, as well as the church of the lady of the hour. I asked around at some of the other destroyed churches, and the construction guys were nice enough to let me in and wonder around. I stayed in hotel Al safer on the west side, which was very basic (squat toilet) but fine for 25k per night. The city feels quite sad, but the security presence is heavy and it's safe. Locals are happy to meet visitors and I got invited to the house of a guy who I met wondering around the destroyed areas. He told me stories of his relatives being killed by Isis and how his house was blown up. Definitely worth going, if you're interested in the recent history of Iraq.

Kurdistan - I was sick for most of the time I was here, unfortunately, but a bit of info. Your federal Iraq visa works to enter here, but not vice versa. Erbil is just ok. Very relaxed, safe, and relatively liberal. The citadel and surrounding bazaar is nice, but there's really not much else to do in the city. Duhok is much nicer, I thought, and allows for interesting day trips. I went to Lalish, the yazidi holy city, and it was fascinating. You can't wear shoes in the whole village, and the architecture is very distinct. They have these conical spires which supposedly absorb the sun, and the whole area is very pretty and mountainous. Can't say much else for Kurdistan unfortunately, due to illness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Money - my Australian card worked in quite a few of the ATMs in Iraq. Some charged fees, some didn't. ATMs are surprisingly scarce though, particularly outside of Baghdad, so if you go to Mosul and Kurdistan, make sure you have sufficient cash. There are also shops that look like Forex places that can act as ATMs, they charge you with an EFTPOS machine and then give you cash. I had mixed success with my card working at these places, though.

Food - typical arab fare, which is to say pretty good. Meat, bread, pickles, hummus, falafel etc. Iraqi shish kebabs are the best I've had anywhere in the world. Shawarma places and other local fast food is ubiquitous on every corner. Try the classic Iraqi roast fish called masgoof. There are also street carts selling boiled chickpeas called 'leblebi' and boiled beets which are a great snack. Karbala and Najaf are also famous for their coconut oil sweets called daheen, which are sickly.

I think that's it for now. Definitely recommend a visit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2402992
Oh, and basra. I flew to Basra from Erbil for the final of the gulf Arab cup football. Got caught in a crowd crush where a dozen people ended up dying because ppl without tickets stormed the gates. Had to bribe my way into the stadium even though I had a ticket. People hanging off the railing and stuff, three to a seat, had a guy literally sitting on my shoulders with his legs dangling. Probably 110k in a 65k capacity stadium. Clearly uncomfortable, but a mental experience that you couldn't really get in many other places, and Iraq ended up winning in an insanely dramatic match, so it was worth it. Basra itself has some interesting stuff by the water, like Saddam's old yacht that's sinking. Didn't stay for too long otherwise though, so can't recommend much else there.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2400965
if you want to stay longer than 3 months in one stay you need a residence permit. To get a residence permit you need an local address, EU passport, proof of funds/income, and european healthcare card. You fill out some paperwork, make a picture, and then you get and residence permit id card. It will cost you less than 100 euro and is done in a week. Though would be easier if you get an local lawyer to help you deal with the immigration office and paper work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2406030
just think about it seriously
set a time limit in your head "i'm gonna analyze my negative thoughts for 30s"
find out the cause of those thoughts. For example, if you had less than stellar experiences with people, see if the cause was external or internal. Or if you failed an interview, maybe you didn't give enough effort in the days leading up to that interview.
Everything have a cause. The shitty part is that seemingly trivial events can have a hold on you for a very long time. That's why we have laws punishing those causing emotional and psychological damages
but the most important thing is to not overthink and shit on yourself. The world doesn't give a fuck if you suffer alone, so kick those thoughts in the balls and man up

I am subscribed to quite a lot of quality channels. Some well known travel vloggers and some touristy/theme park/coaster channels that deserve more subscribers. Here's a list of the ones i watch the most:
Obvious channels/100k+ subscribers:
>Backpacker Ben
https://youtube.com/@BackpackerBen
Brit who has done videos with Bald but is way more likeable and relatable to the average traveler
>Dale Philip
https://youtube.com/@Dale_Philip
One of the more tolerable food guys
>Kurt Caz
https://youtube.com/@KurtCaz
Puts himself in some seriously fucked up places and situations, consistently A+ content
>Super Enthused
https://youtube.com/@SuperEnthused
One of the only bearable theme park vloggers with a lot of subscribers. I mostly only watch her non-disney uploads.
Grimmlifecollective:
https://youtube.com/@grimmlifecollective
Goth freaks but interesting vids & niche movie-related sights
Hidden gem channels:
>My Expat Diary:
https://youtube.com/@MyExpatDiary
German vlogger who comes off as genuine/authentic and has honest opinions
>Kyde & Eric
https://youtube.com/@kydeanderic
US expats living in Japan. Have 700+ vlogs covering most of the country. Can sometimes be annoying but not too bad.
>Near From Home
https://youtube.com/@NearFromHome
Best Germany channel
>Jacob the Carpetbagger
https://youtube.com/@TheCarpetbagger
Best US roadside attractions channel on YouTube. Can be obnoxious but you get used to it after a few videos.
Nobodies but showing promise:
>Obscurist Tourist
https://youtube.com/@ObscuristTourist
US vlogger/roadside tourism
>Ray Out There
https://youtube.com/@RayOutThere
boring personality but decent roadside vlogs
>Roadside Explorers
https://youtube.com/@RoadsideExplorers
Their vlogs arent that well shot but their content is curated very well for kitsch culture/Americana. Great docs of defunct shit from around the US.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2400758
You sound young so I'll give you advice.
Putting yourself in uncomfortable situations is good but forcing yourself to go clubbing when you don't like it is stupid.
What kind of music do you like? If there's anything electronic then try and find a club night that plays that, just going to a generic club night for the sake of it will be shit especially if you're by yourself.
No one wears ear plugs so you'll look even weirder.
Unless you go to a fetish club it won't be "fetishy"
tl;dr don't bother, going out of your comfort zone means speaking to people you ordinarily wouldn't or trying food you don't know, it doesn't mean doing stuff that you dislike in a different country - turns out you'll just have a shit time

I do and have gone clubbing solo but only on nights with music that I like so if you're just there trying to meet women it'll be obvious.
Munich is an awesome place with a great drinking culture, as I said in my last message you don't need to do shit that you don't like just to meet people.
If you're into rock music I'm sure there will be gigs you can go to, depending on time of year they have a massive rock festival called rock am park close by which is great.
If you want to meet people just stay in a hostel and hang out in the communal areas and talk to women there, you can then ask them to go out and it's alot more organic than trying to pull at a German club. Just check on somewhere like hostel world and pick the ones with the best atmosphere ratings and highest rated, it's pretty easy, if you've got a bit of money then get your own room there - easiest time ever. wtf are you on. europe has tons of rock and metal clubs. northern europe especially, but you'll find the token rock bar in every town basically, with club nights and all.
see also >>2403964
yeah, the drugs taken are different, so in rock and metal environments it's mostly gonna be alcohol consumed, maybe some joints or whatever. the music is different, but that's about it.
in bigger cities you even have clubs where it's techno and house in one room, and metal and doom in another room... it's fun.

ultimately i strongly agree with >>2400905. seriously, if you don't feel like it, you don't have to do it. if you are curious, cause you want to see how others are in different countries when they go to clubs... do it, but then i recommend arriving wayy later than the announced start time of the event that night. at least 2 hours later, maybe even more. by that time people get drunk or high or just get into the party mood their own way, and you won't have to be there during the moment when everyone is just looking at each other, trying to read the mood.
